item.title: 10 Mbps, 100 Mbps, 1000 Mbps Internet Upgrades
item.description: By: John Shepler Are you frustrated with your company’s slow internet speeds? It’s understandable. Today’s applications are much more demanding than the simple websites and text-based emails common when T1 lines were first introduced. A 10 Mbps connection is now the bare minimum for most businesses, and it’s reasonable to need 100 Mbps or even 1000 Mbps. So, how can you upgrade effectively? Upgrading Your Connection One option is to gradually increase your bandwidth as your needs grow.

item.title: 100 Mbps Internet for Business
item.description: For many mid-size businesses, DS3 internet with its 45 Mbps speed has been the standard. It’s widely available and offered a significant upgrade from older T1 lines. However, with the rise of video conferencing and cloud-based applications, even DS3 struggles to handle the demands of multiple users. It’s time to consider upgrading to 100 Mbps internet access. The 100 Mbps service level is significant because it aligns with “Fast” Ethernet, a standard Ethernet LAN speed.

item.title: Fiber Optic Leased Lines for Business
Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport Offers Huge Advantages
item.description: By: John Shepler Data can be moved in many ways. The new top choice is Fiber Optic Ethernet, known as EoF or Ethernet over Fiber, which offers excellent value. What is Fiber Optic Ethernet Transport? When fiber optic lines were first installed, Ethernet wasn’t a factor. The standard was SONET (Synchronous Optical NETworking), designed to carry existing DS1 and DS3 phone calls on fiber. Fiber offered significantly more bandwidth than copper twisted pair, microwave, or coaxial cable.

item.title: Cyber Monday is For Business Buyers Too
item.description: By: John Shepler Cyber Monday is known for online shopping deals that shoppers couldn’t get in crowded stores during Black Friday sales. While there are many consumer deals, businesses need to consider their savings opportunities as well. Business spending is a significant part of the economy, and their savings can lead to lower prices for consumers. Taking advantage of Cyber Monday bargains is a win-win situation for everyone. Businesses should explore potential savings on services they might not typically consider.

item.title: GigE and FastE Bandwidth Services
item.description: Companies routinely upgrade their bandwidth from older technologies like T1 lines to faster Ethernet options, often without significant cost increases. However, for those requiring substantial bandwidth, choices beyond these basic levels are necessary. Carrier Ethernet is becoming the preferred choice for medium to high bandwidth needs, replacing traditional DS3, T3, and SONET technologies. Ethernet offers cost advantages and greater flexibility in provisioning. Lower bandwidth Ethernet services commonly utilize existing copper telephone lines.

item.title: Lock In Telecom Cost Savings For Next Year
item.description: As we wrap up the year and analyze our performance, it’s common to wonder if we’re overspending on business operations, especially networking and telecom. A thorough market analysis often reveals opportunities to secure better rates for the same services. By doing this now, you can lock in savings for the entire next year. Why are such savings possible? Primarily, increased competition and technological advancements. Previously, businesses were limited to local telephone companies for their communication needs.

item.title: Internet Wholesale Bandwidth Options
item.description: Two main types of organizations buy internet bandwidth: end users and resellers. End users, such as businesses, need access for their employees. Resellers, also known as Internet Service Providers (ISPs), purchase large amounts of bandwidth and divide it among numerous individuals and businesses, aiming to profit from the difference between wholesale and retail prices. The biggest networks, called Tier 1, are integral to the internet’s core and don’t purchase access. Instead, they exchange traffic equally with other Tier 1 networks through a process called peering, which benefits all without financial transactions.

item.title: Fiber Ethernet WAN Bandwidth Advantages
item.description: Larger companies often need more internet bandwidth than what’s typically offered through standard copper wire connections. While fiber optic cables provide a solution with almost limitless bandwidth, finding a cost-effective option is key. Businesses already utilizing fiber optic bandwidth might be leasing older SONET/SDH services like OC3, OC12, or OC48 for their wide area network needs. These traditional telecom services, originally designed for high-volume phone calls, have been adapted to handle today’s demand for high-bandwidth data connections.

item.title: Ethernet In The First Mile Advantages
item.description: Metropolitan and Wide Area Networks can send your data anywhere you want. To access these networks, you need a connection known as “first mile” or “last mile” connectivity. Ethernet offers advantages for this first mile link. Several technologies, such as T1 lines, DSL, SONET fiber optic services, and even microwave or 3G/4G wireless, work well for first mile connections. These options connect your building to your service provider or a gateway to their network.

item.title: Ethernet Over Fiber Needed By Business
item.description: While many believe fiber optic bandwidth is the way of the future, it’s already a smart choice for businesses today. Traditionally, businesses have depended on copper-based telecom services. The copper wiring integrated during a building’s construction becomes the backbone for multi-line phone systems, ISDN digital trunking for PBX systems, and T1 lines connecting offices and providing broadband internet. This infrastructure has been the standard for many small and medium-sized businesses for decades.

item.title: Benefits of Migrating From T1 to Fiber
item.description: By: John Shepler While T1 lines have proven their reliability over decades, sticking with them solely due to past success might not be the best strategy. This article explores compelling reasons to consider alternatives. Why T1 Lines Were Once Favored T1’s strength lies in its established design and history. Developed for clear long-distance phone connections, T-Carrier technology, encompassing T1, E1, and T3 (DS3), evolved to handle data packets alongside voice calls due to its digital nature.

item.title: Shopping For High Speed Options
item.description: The landscape of business broadband has undergone significant changes. While options were once limited and expensive, today’s market offers a variety of affordable high-speed solutions. For instance, T1 lines, previously exceeding $1,000, now cost around $300 for most locations and offer speeds of 1.5 Mbps or higher with bonding. An alternative, Ethernet over Copper (EoC), provides 2-3 Mbps at a similar price point and allows for easier scalability compared to T1’s jump to DS3.

item.title: 20/20 Mbps Speed on Copper and Fiber
item.description: By: John Shepler Business broadband needs have increased steadily, driven by the shift from text-based information to multimedia and the migration of business operations to cloud services. Simple, low-speed connections are no longer sufficient, with basic internet speeds now reaching tens of Mbps. A common choice for smaller businesses and remote workers is a 20/20 Mbps connection. This speed adequately supports individual users, small teams, or retail locations while remaining affordable.

item.title: What is Ethernet Service?
item.description: Business-grade Carrier Ethernet services are gaining popularity. If you’re curious about Ethernet and its potential benefits, read on. Ethernet dominates as a LAN protocol. It’s remarkable how quickly it outpaced competitors. Switched Ethernet is nearly ubiquitous. A similar shift is happening with telecom services, moving from traditional circuit-switched technologies to packet-switched networks that align better with modern devices. Ethernet is poised to become the standard for both metropolitan and long-distance networks.

item.title: Ethernet Providers in Hot Competition
item.description: While demand for bandwidth increases, budgets remain tight. Ethernet WAN connections offer a new solution to this problem. This technology has become a strong alternative to traditional T1 lines, leading to fierce competition among Ethernet providers vying for the best deals. The buzz surrounding Ethernet, a protocol used in LANs for years, stems from its standardization as a carrier technology by the Metro Ethernet Forum (MEF). This has propelled Ethernet services from LANs to MANs and WANs in just a few years, turning it from a niche product into the preferred transport service.

item.title: 1000 Mbps SONET or Gigabit Ethernet Options
item.description: With growing bandwidth demands, businesses are turning to WAN network speeds that were once impractical. The competition within the bandwidth market has made 1,000 Mbps or Gigabit Ethernet (GigE) more affordable than one might expect. The cost per Mbps has dropped significantly in recent years, while availability has increased. This is beneficial for businesses adopting cloud computing or those with substantial bandwidth requirements, such as medical facilities, content creators and distributors, and Internet service providers.

item.title: Zayo Lights Denver With Expanded Fiber Optic Network Services
item.description: Zayo Group, a prominent fiber optic bandwidth infrastructure provider, is expanding its existing metro fiber network coverage in Denver and Colorado Springs. The expansion project will add 521 miles of fiber along the Colorado Front Range, encompassing cities like Boulder, Longmont, Loveland, Greeley, and Fort Collins. This increase brings Zayo’s total fiber optic network in the Denver area to 900 route miles, supporting industries such as research, technology, education, and energy.

item.title: Point to Point Fiber Optic Connections
item.description: By: John Shepler Let’s say you need a secure connection with decent bandwidth between two business sites. Should you use the internet, or is there a better option? The Benefits of Private Lines The internet has two main advantages: global reach and affordability. However, it also has two significant drawbacks: inconsistent performance and security vulnerabilities. A superior alternative is private lines, specifically dedicated point-to-point connections. These are genuinely private. Security is greatly enhanced because accessing a network you’re not connected to is incredibly difficult.

item.title: Gigabit Ethernet over Fiber to Your Door
item.description: Many modern businesses rely on data-heavy applications, such as cloud services and video production, which can overwhelm the capacity of traditional internet services. Insufficient bandwidth leads to frustrating consequences, including reduced productivity, delayed file transfers, and disrupted communication. Thankfully, effective solutions are becoming increasingly accessible. Meeting high bandwidth demands requires high bandwidth solutions. Older technologies like T1 lines and even DS3 bandwidth (45 Mbps) have become insufficient for many businesses. While Ethernet over Copper and fixed wireless offer improved speeds (50-100 Mbps), they too are becoming inadequate.

item.title: Disruptive Metro Ethernet over Fiber Pricing Arrives
item.description: The increasing use of Ethernet over Fiber (EoF) by large companies, as a cheaper option compared to SONET fiber optic services, has made many believe that fiber optic technology is only for big players. However, that notion is no longer true, as affordable fiber optic bandwidth is now accessible to all. The surprising reason behind the unexpectedly low cost of Mbps or Gbps bandwidth, often half the anticipated price or even less, is Cable TV.
